en: Interview with Adesola Odunayo, clinical associate professor with the University of Tennessee College of Veterinary Medicine. Odunayo discusses the challenges of treating animals that were harmed during the wildfires. She also recounts seeing families reunited with their pets and the emotional impact of the experience. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: The local thing we did was using hyperbaric oxygen, which is a treatment where an animal is put into an oxygen chamber usually for an hour. And the whole goal of that is to try to just increase oxygen delivery to the wound and in theory that should kind of help accelerate healing of the wound in the tissues in the areas.

Interview with Adesola Odunayo, clinical associate professor with the University of Tennessee College of Veterinary Medicine. Odunayo discusses the challenges of treating animals that were harmed during the wildfires. She also recounts seeing families reunited with their pets and the emotional impact of the experience. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: The local thing we did was using hyperbaric oxygen, which is a treatment where an animal is put into an oxygen chamber usually for an hour. And the whole goal of that is to try to just increase oxygen delivery to the wound and in theory that should kind of help accelerate healing of the wound in the tissues in the areas.

Can you state your name and tell us about your role at the university?
What is a typical day for you like?
Can you tell us about your experiences in the days and weeks leading up to the wildfires?
What was it like coming home after being in Japan during the fires?
When you returned, it sounds like the clinic had already started bringing in animals?
Were there any other facilities in the area that were providing critical care during this time?
Were any of the first responders bringing in animals?
What were some of the injuries that you were treating?
Were you able to use any past experiences in how to treat these animals?
What were some of the ways that you were able to treat the cats with severe burns?
Can you tell us about Topper the cat?
How were the cats able to recover from their burns? Did they have their pads removed?
For cats that weren't brought in by their owners, how did they get reunited?
Was there any research published based upon what was learned during this?
What's the difference in cats being able to survive a fire versus other animals?
What was the experience like when you saw families reunite with their pets?
Was there any emotional impact for you in seeing and dealing with these animals?
Were you provided with any counseling from the university?
Dealing with 18 cats at once, how were those costs managed?
Do you know if there was an emotional impact on the cats?
Is there anything that we haven't talked about that you would like to mention?

seo.title: Interview with Adesola Odunayo, 2020-04-23 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
seo.description: Interview with Adesola Odunayo, clinical associate professor with the University of Tennessee College of Veterinary Medicine. Odunayo discusses the challenges of treating animals that were harmed during the wildfires. She also recounts seeing families reunited with their pets and the emotional impact of the experience. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: The local thing we did was using hyperbaric oxygen, which is a treatment where an animal is put into an oxygen chamber usually for an hour. And the whole goal of that is to try to just increase oxygen delivery to the wound and in theory that should kind of help accelerate healing of the wound in the tissues in the areas.
